# Ecological characteristics of the tree species

## Tree species

![](images/species_characters.png){fig-align="center"}

## Behaviour in monoculture stands {.smaller}

::::: columns
::: {.column .center width="50%"}
-   Scots Pine grows well on poor soils, uniform stands, and have a high drought and pest vulnerability.
-   European Beech dense canopy and quality timber, drought sensitive, limited regeneration on dry sites.
-   Sessile Oak: valuable hardwood, requires light, regeneration difficult, risk from insects. Norway Spruce: fast growth, high yield, prone to storms and bark beetles.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/oak_pine_mono.png){fig-align="center" width="60%"}
:::
:::::

## Synergies in mixed stands

![](images/interactions.png){fig-align="center"}

## Trade-offs and competition in mixed stands

-   Beech/Pine: Beech overtops pine over time
-   Oak/Beech: Oak needs more light.
-   Spruce competes with beech for moisture because it performs poorly on dry soils.
-   There is the need for proper management to balance competition and maintain mixture stability.

**Key point**: from Pine monoculture to resilient mixed forest

# Silvicultural strategies

## Business as usual (BAS) {.smaller}

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
-   Non-intervention approach; stand develops naturally.

-   Relies on succession, mortality, and regeneration.

-   Minimal management cost and labor required.

-   Used as a control or baseline scenario.

-   Risk of instability and poor timber quality.

-   Beech regeneration limited under dense pine canopy.

-   Natural growth → Self-thinning → Harvest
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/apa_unmanaged_natural_pine.jpg){fig-align="center"}
:::
:::::

## Set it and forget it (SIAFI) {.smaller}

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
-   Low-maintenance method for long-term sustainability.

-   Identify and mark future crop trees early (Z-Bäume).

-   Release them from competition every five years.

-   Balance between management cost and growth quality.

-   Species-specific thinning applied by intensity.

-   Promotes quality target trees with limited intervention

-   Crop tree selection → Competitor removal → Monitoring → Repeat
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/apa_zbaum_method.jpg){fig-align="center"}
:::
:::::

## High effort (HE) {.smaller}

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
-   Intensive management with strong release thinnings.

-   Select and monitor high-potential crop trees.

-   Adjust thinning intensity dynamically per growth response.

-   Repeat thinning every five years, adaptive approach.

-   Maximizes timber quality and regeneration success.

-   High labor and supervision cost required.

-   Risk of instability if over-thinned

-   Dynamic crop tree selection → Strong release thinning → Monitoring → Repeat
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/apa_thinning.png){fig-align="center"}
:::
:::::

## Comparison of BAS, SIAFI, and HE {.smaller}

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
-   BAS: Natural development, low cost, slow results.

-   SIAFI: Moderate effort, sustainable long-term option.

-   HE: High cost but fast and flexible regeneration.

-   Beech regeneration: slow → moderate → fast.

-   Biodiversity improvement: low → medium → high.

-   Management intensity: minimal → moderate → high.

-   Choice depends on ecological and economic goals.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/apa_thinning_principles.png){fig-align="center"}
:::
:::::

## SIAFI

### Future Crop Trees

| Parameter Class | Parameter            | Value   |
|-----------------|----------------------|---------|
| Frequency       | Thinning periods     | 5 years |
| Intensity       | Release radius       | 4 m     |
|                 | Max. thinning volume | 150 m³  |

## SIAFI

| Species        | Future Crop Trees [^2] / ha | Thinning regime        |
|----------------|-----------------------------|------------------------|
| Scots pine     | 80                          | light                  |
| European beech | 22                          | heavy                  |
| Norway spruce  | 0                           | light                  |
| Sessile oak    | 40                          | no direct thinning[^3] |

[^2]: $(N\ \text{Future trees monoculture})_i \times (\text{Target proportion})_i$ // $i = Species$

[^3]: Summand = 0

## HE

### Selective thinning

| Parameter Class | Parameter                | Value    |
|-----------------|--------------------------|----------|
| Frequency       | Thinning periods         | 5 years  |
| Intensity       | Tree numbers             | variable |
|                 | Max. thinning volume     | 150 m³   |
|                 | A-Value                  | Strong   |
|                 | Species thinning regimes | = SIAFI  |
